messages.subject: Re: Another tanto
messages.msgSnippet: John: Thanks for the info!...quite a resource; I saved it for future reference. I worked with the tanto yesterday and was able to bring up some midare
messages.messageBody:
John:

Thanks for the info!...quite a resource; I saved it for future
reference.

I worked with the tanto yesterday and was able to bring up some
midare utsuri...mainly on one side.

Thanks again,
Ron

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "John Small nagelgone"
<saemonjonosuke@h...> wrote:
> Hello Ron,
>
> It is always difficult to judge a sukesada.
> For my feeling the blades is not from eisho period.
>
> I have a very big database,,, so maybe this will help you to
search and

> Greetings,
> John Klein Nagelvoort
> The Netherlands

> >I came across a tanto that I was trying to determine whether was
> >genuine:
> >http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto1.jpg

> >http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto3.jpg

> >Tanto is signed "Bishu Osafune Ju Sukesada", and dated "Eisho
(1504)
> >2nd Year, 2nd Month"
> >Pretty, complex hada with wide ribbons of chikei.
> >No kizu.
> >Hamon is gunome, nioi deki with subtle ashi and hard spots along
the
> >habuchi.
> >I couldn't locate the smith in my resources. (seems like there are
> >40+ Sukesadas)
> >
> >Questions:
> >1)Does the work fit? (I would have thought more activity in the
> >hamon) Work looks more like Kanemitsu school..(which I guess is
> >Osafune also)
> >2)How does one separate kazuuchi-mono from the custom work?
> >3)Any opinions on the mei?
> >
> >Thanks very much for looking!
> >Ron P.
> >ps the nagasa is 26.8 cm

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Matthew, Yes I am a member. What shell a saw about the Dutch Token soc. Maybe you have so visit them and see by your self. Mr.Han Bing Siong is our chairman
messages.messageBody:
Hi Matthew,

Yes I am a member.
What shell a saw about the Dutch Token soc.
Maybe you have so visit them and see by your self.

Mr.Han Bing Siong is our chairman and I learned a lot from him my 12 years
membership.
If you know, Holland is a small country and if you want to study Nihonto,
then the Dutch Token is a good study club to see sword and related items.

John

It is always difficult to judge a sukesada.
For my feeling the blades is not from eisho period.

I have a very big database,,, so maybe this will help you to search and
study the koto Sukesada.

John Klein Nagelvoort

>From: "Ron Polansky" <rpolansky@...>
>Reply-To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
>To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [nihontostudy] Another tanto
>Date: Sun, 29 Jun 2003 18:02:37 -0000
>
>Gentlemen:
>
>I came across a tanto that I was trying to determine whether was
>genuine:
>http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto1.jpg
>http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto2.jpg
>http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto3.jpg
>http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto4.jpg
>http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto5.jpg
>Tanto is signed "Bishu Osafune Ju Sukesada", and dated "Eisho (1504)
>2nd Year, 2nd Month"
>Pretty, complex hada with wide ribbons of chikei.
>No kizu.
>Hamon is gunome, nioi deki with subtle ashi and hard spots along the
>habuchi.
>I couldn't locate the smith in my resources. (seems like there are
>40+ Sukesadas)
>
>Questions:
>1)Does the work fit? (I would have thought more activity in the
>hamon) Work looks more like Kanemitsu school..(which I guess is
>Osafune also)
>2)How does one separate kazuuchi-mono from the custom work?
>3)Any opinions on the mei?
>
>Thanks very much for looking!
>Ron P.
>ps the nagasa is 26.8 cm
>
>

study the koto Sukesada.

John Klein Nagelvoort

messages.subject: Another tanto
messages.msgSnippet: Gentlemen: I came across a tanto that I was trying to determine whether was genuine: http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto1.jpg
messages.messageBody:
Gentlemen:

I came across a tanto that I was trying to determine whether was
genuine:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto2.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto3.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto4.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Tanto5.jpg
Tanto is signed "Bishu Osafune Ju Sukesada", and dated "Eisho (1504)
2nd Year, 2nd Month"
Pretty, complex hada with wide ribbons of chikei.
No kizu.
Hamon is gunome, nioi deki with subtle ashi and hard spots along the
habuchi.
I couldn't locate the smith in my resources. (seems like there are
40+ Sukesadas)

Questions:
1)Does the work fit? (I would have thought more activity in the
hamon) Work looks more like Kanemitsu school..(which I guess is
Osafune also)
2)How does one separate kazuuchi-mono from the custom work?
3)Any opinions on the mei?

Thanks very much for looking!
Ron P.
ps the nagasa is 26.8 cm
